Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Late Cretaceous-Paleogene Vertebrates from Antarctica: Implications for Paleobiogeography, Paleoenvironment, and Extinction in Polar Gondwana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The role that Antarctica has played in vertebrate evolution and paleobiogeography during the Late Cretaceous and early Paleogene is largely unknown. Evidence indicates that Antarctica was home to a diverse flora during the Late Cretaceous and Paleogene, yet the vertebrates that must have existed on the continent remain virtually unknown. To fill this gap, the PIs have formed the Antarctic Vertebrate Paleontology Initiative (AVPI), whose goal is to search for and collect Late Cretaceous-Paleogene vertebrate fossils in Antarctica at localities that have never been properly surveyed, as well as in areas of proven potential. Two field seasons are proposed for the James Ross Island Group on the northeastern margin of the Antarctic Peninsula. Expected finds include chondrichthyan and osteichthyan fishes, marine reptiles, ornithischian and non-avian theropod dinosaurs, ornithurine birds, and therian and non-therian mammals. Hypotheses to be tested include: 1) multiple extant bird and/or therian mammal lineages originated during the Cretaceous and survived the K-Pg boundary extinction event; 2) the ?Scotia Portal? permitted the dispersal of continental vertebrates between Antarctica and South America prior to the latest Cretaceous and through to the late Paleocene or early Eocene; 3) Late Cretaceous non-avian dinosaurs from Antarctica are closely related to coeval taxa from other Gondwanan landmasses; 4) terminal Cretaceous marine reptile faunas from southern Gondwana differed from contemporaneous but more northerly assemblages; and 5) the collapse of Antarctic ichthyofaunal diversity during the K-Pg transition was triggered by a catastrophic extinction.

Broader impacts:
The PIs will communicate discoveries to audiences through a variety of channels, such as the Dinosaurs in Their Time exhibition at Carnegie Museum of Natural History and the outreach programs of the Environmental Science Institute of the University of Texas at Austin. In addition, Carnegie Museum will launch a student-oriented programming initiative using AVPI research as a primary focus. This array of activities will help some 2,000 Pittsburgh-area undergraduates to explore the relevance of deep-time discoveries to critical modern issues. The AVPI will provide research opportunities for eight undergraduate and three graduate students, several of whom will receive field training in Antarctica. Fossils will be accessioned into the Carnegie Museum collection, and made accessible virtually through the NSF-funded Digital Morphology library at University of Texas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team received National Science Foundation support to recover fossil evidence of vertebrates in Antarctica, from geological contexts between 80 and 40 million years old. Dinosaur, bird, and mammal specialists were involved in this research; this report on outcomes relates to mammals. Our overall purpose was to establish, using fossil evidence as well as new molecular techniques, what role Antarctica may have played at this early time in shaping mammalian diversity and distributions.

Two extraordinary events occurred within this time period that impacted the entire planet, and, quite possibly, the course of mammalian evolution. The first was the extinction, 66 million years ago, of nonavian dinosaurs (and approximately 75% of everything else then living). Although the loss of biodiversity was dreadful, for survivors it opened new possibilities, such as the opportunity to enter new ecological contexts. Most scientists agree that seems to be exactly what happened with placental mammals, whose diversity suddenly burgeoned at this time.

The other event was an interval of intense warming at the start of the Eocene epoch 55 million years ago, when global temperatures rose 8-10 degrees Celsius, to slowly trail off thereafter. At this time many modern groups of placentals (e.g., primates and ungulates of modern aspect) appear for the first time in the fossil record. By 40 million years ago, however, major global cooling, high-latitude glaciation, and marked climatic zonation of the sort we still have today had been initiated---and marked the last time it would have been possible for terrestrial vertebrates to survive anywhere in Antarctica. Thus any contributions that Antarctica might have made to mammalian diversity and distribution had to have occurred before then.

Outcome 1: For the earlier part of the study interval, 80-66 million years ago, our emphasis was on trying to recover any evidence at all of mammal presence in Antarctica. For several theoretical reasons, it is highly likely that the ancestors of Australian marsupials were in West and East Antarctica at least as early as 80 million years ago (as well as members of other groups, including a number of so-called nontherian mammals who have left no descendants other than monotremes). In this effort we were unsuccessful, although other team members were able to make important discoveries of dinosaur, plesiosaur, bird and fish fossils.

Outcome 2: We were much more successful with the second, or early Cenozoic, part of the interval, although success came from applying new techniques not envisaged at the start of the research. Two highly distinctive groups of placental mammals suddenly appear in the South American paleontological record during this period---the xenarthrans (sloths, armadillos, and anteaters) and the South American native ungulates (or SANUs, a wholly extinct group). Although Africa has frequently been claimed to be the ultimate homeland of these groups, the only early Cenozoic hard evidence for them is South American---except for a small handful of species known from Antarctica (specifically, the Eocene of Seymour Island). Did they actually differentiate in Antarctica, from still earlier ancestral groups, when it was still possible for land mammals to live there? Our approach to this question was to attempt to assemble evidence that would be useful for estimating their time of origin (technically, divergence time) using not only fossil evidence but also the information content of proteins such as collagen. Proteins are specified by genes, and using mass spectrometry to determine their amino acid composition. DNA survives poorly (less than 1 million years), but structural proteins like collagen can last much longer. By gathering protein evidence for a wide range of modern mammals and a number of extinct xenarthrans and SANUs, and calibrating this information against fossil occurrences in deep time, we developed divergence estimates that suggest origins for both groups well back in our period of interest, 66-75 million years ago. This is not decisive evidence for the existence of Mesozoic Antarctic xenarthrans and SANUs—only fossils can provide that—but it is a reason for continuing the hunt and thereby uncovering what is still a most obscure chapter in placental evolution.  Our efforts to successfully collect protein evidence from Antarctic fossils also continues, as the persistently cold temperatures of the past 40 million years should have significantly slowed degradation. As a new tool in paleontological research, proteomics (as the field is called) should have a bright future.
